A stylistic analysis of Quattrocento prefaces to translations from the Greek, undertaken some years ago by Lucia Gualdo Rosa,¹ has demonstrated their close stylistic similan‘ty to Latin prose prefaces of late Antiquity‚² a similan’ty which was enhanced by the analogous circumstances under which these prefaces were composed: the society of the late empire, as well as that of the Italian city states, favoured clientela relations; and many literary works of late Antiquity were compilations and imitations which, like translations, would not call for inventio. Dedicatory letters are furthermore a very conven- tional kind of writing, and their form, once established, would not often be subject to change.
